Hey guys,

I don't know if anybody cares, but I just tried a trick that a lot of 
the P&S digital guys
are doing  - they reverse a lens in front of the lens on their camera - 
this appears to work
real well on these due to their smaller lens geometry/built in zoom. 
 However,  I wanted to
see if this would work on a DSLR. So I scrounged up an old nikon 50mm lens
(you can get these dirt cheep) and tried that reversed on my 50mm lens. 
 the result
was this:

http://home.teleport.com/~rkg/misc/gumby2.jpg

This suuucks - you can see the vignetting/blockage  around the edges :-(

Before just putting the piece up on ebay, I decided to try it reversed 
on a 105mm macro.
(and here's the obligatory nihonto related content) - this is a picture 
of an iris on a kashira
that I have - note that I didn't take much time in the setup (used a 
lamp for lighting and
wagged the white balance) and the camera is at a complex and incorrect 
angle
relative to the surface (so not a lot of its in focus), but...

http://home.teleport.com/~rkg/misc/extreme_deux.jpg

You can see it just starting to vignette in the very corners, but a 
little crop, and...

Not as flexible as a mp-e 65, but it doesn't cost $800 either....

Just had to share...

rkg
(Richard George)
